It's been de-emphasized since Japan started getting westernized and especially since WW2, but in the feudal era the prevailing belief was that the plain of existence that the gods were created in and resided in was in the celestial heavens and they descended to Earth through a giant bird spaceship. There was a divide between "Amatsukami," gods who resided in heaven, and "Kunitsukami," gods who resided on earth. The moon was a separate land with its own population, with the myth of Kaguya telling of a girl from the moon being sent to the Earth to be raised by humans before returning home. The main role of these distinctions is to emphasize to the common superstitious fools which elements of existence are within the control of mortals and which ones aren't. Is the sun being obnoxiously hot and ruining your harvest through drought? Too bad, Amaterasu the sun goddess is an Amatsukami and doesn't give a flying fuck about you, tough it out. But maybe you can pray to one of the local Kunitsukami (read: learn about proper drought-control measures) to help you get through it. Likewise the folk story about Kaguya presents her as immensely perfect and desired by all, to teach the lesson that perfection is inhuman and celestial, therefore don't strive for it like a waifufag.

This really isn't anything special since a lot of mythologies have some celestial heavenly place in the sky where the gods live, but if you're going to accurately depict that in a story created since the late 20th century then it's going to come across as "the gods are space aliens." Sci-fi and fantasy have always been intrinsically connected.

I was reading through 13th Age's Book of the Underworld (i.e. its version of the underground/Underdark/Khyber), and I found this interesting area:
>LAND BEYOND THE AGES
>Go deep enough, and time itself breaks down. The remnants of past ages, preserved in Caverns of Lost Time (page 49) slowly sink through the earth until they collapse and flow together, merging and losing their identities as they blend with times that will be, might be, and never were or will be.

In this book, the Land Beyond the Ages is categorized as one of the areas that only the highest-level of PCs should enter, and only when they absolutely need to save the world.

This place is essentially the GM's cutting room floor. It is where all of the GM's unused ideas go: NPCs, monsters, towns, dungeons, items, setting details, plot hooks, adventure outlines. They are all here, lying around in limbo. Some might be brought into the campaign eventually, perhaps in a repurposed form, while others languish as campaign elements that were deemed completely unviable. More importantly, the Land Beyond the Ages also contains elements of potential futures: ideas that the GM has for future sessions, but has not fully committed to.

Is it very PC-centric, as if the world revolves around the party? Yes. But that is part of why it is a high-level area.

threads.com: Basically, I’m still working out some of their backstory and a fuckton of specifics and side stories, but as an overview, they’re a splitoff of early Clan Moulder that settled under a big mountain near the east of the Mountains of Mourn to siphon energy off of the Great Maw for power (hence the name). They succeeded and eventually even caused their own smaller Skaven version of the Great Maw to be born as a greater daemon of the Horned Rat, but it permanently altered them, giving them both the desire and the ability to grow and consume more, better food to the point that they have their own underground ecosystem that they farm and even their slaves are chubby, leaving them tougher but slower moving. This led to them all constantly poisoning each other until they finally decided to operate on merit to avoid annihilating themselves, though not to the extent of Clan Mors, as they lack any unique bravery for Skaven and also lack any true loyalty very far beyond “Let’s not annihilate ourselves by all backstabbing each other.” When they come of age, they must prove how “useful-worthwhile” they are to determine their rank and status in the clan; their very most ambitious often even leave to go on a quest to bring back something valuable to prove their worth at this time in their lives (like a Quarian pilgrimage, almost). Those that actually survive to bring something back essentially always wind up in a good position. Their frustration over the lack of backstabbing manifests itself through a love of aggressive flanking attacks. They also sell substantial amounts of slaves (their slaves need more food but are a lot harder to work to death, making them a valuable commodity) and cheaper, easier-to-grow versions of their food, making them almost as rich as some of the poorer Council clans. They also gradually took in a number of engineers that eventually fostered an interest in machinery.

last_replies.com: They as of End Times have about a tenth the manufacturing capacity and about a fifth the fleshcrafting capacity as Skryre and Moulder respectively, though they export none of this for fear of angering those two by infringing on their market and even buy a good deal from both, instead hoarding it mostly for the upper fifth or so of their society and military. This upper fifth is insanely well equipped on the battlefield, with the rest of their clanrats using mainly torches and pitchforks like a lynch mob with the occasional (perhaps every fifth to tenth rat) built, bought, looted, or stolen firearm like a musket, pistol, or blunderbuss. They drifted into Clan Eshin’s orbit during the Skaven civil war due to their proximity, so they can get away with a lot more than most non-Council clans as Eshin blocks any motions to eliminate them. They have occasionally been forced to be on the frontlines of major Skaven wars when the Council thinks they’re being too uppity though, most notably during the war of the Black Death where they were clobbered hard to the point that their military was in utter shambles because they tried to replace Clan Verms when it fell, and they would never again make a (remotely blatant) bid at joining the council.
